conversation.message: Dear School_C admissions team, I’m Student_D and School_C is my first choice. I’m very eager to join your community and would like to formally apply. If admitted, I will accept and commit promptly. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd after Student_C and Student_B). If I apply immediately, I have a decent chance to be accepted unless both Student_C and Student_B apply there first. Since this is round 1 and seats are limited everywhere, I should pursue my top option right away rather than risk losing it.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. We appreciate your clear commitment and interest in our community.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. If you still intend to commit promptly, please confirm your acceptance.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority ranking is Student_C > Student_B > Student_D > Student_E > Student_A. Student_D is applying now and ranks 3rd on my list, and School_C is their first choice, so acceptance would lock in a solid match. However, Student_C (my top choice) prefers School_D then School_A then School_B before School_C, so they are unlikely to apply to me early unless rejected elsewhere. Student_B ranks me last, so also unlikely. Student_E is only talking and ranks below Student_D on my list. Given quota 1 and the low likelihood of receiving an application from Student_C or Student_B soon, accepting Student_D now maximizes expected outcome and avoids ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team. I’m Student_E, and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m very interested in your program and community. Could you share what you prioritize most when considering applicants, and whether demonstrating clear first-choice interest matters in your decision process? I’d love to understand how I can best present my fit for School_C.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but I am only 4th in School_C's priority list, so an early [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. School_D is my 4th choice, but I am 2nd in School_D's priority list, giving me a strong chance to secure a match quickly. Since the objective is to maximize my true outcome, I will first [TALK] with School_C to signal strong interest and learn what they value before committing, while keeping School_D as a strong fallback in the next round if needed.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for reaching out and for sharing that School_C is your first choice. In our review, we prioritize overall fit with School_C’s academic expectations and community values, including demonstrated preparation (coursework/achievement), consistent effort and growth, and contributions you’re likely to make to our school culture. Clear first-choice interest can be a helpful signal of fit and commitment, but it is considered alongside the full application profile rather than as a standalone deciding factor.

At the moment, our available seat has been filled in this round, so we are not in a position to extend an offer right now. If circumstances change later, we can re-engage—please feel free to keep in touch and share any concise updates that best reflect your fit for School_C.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and already accepted/matched with Student_D this round; remaining quota is 0, so we cannot accept any additional applicants. Student_E is contacting with [TALK], so we should respond with [TALK] and be transparent that our seat is currently filled, while keeping the door open if circumstances change in later rounds. Provide general guidance on what we prioritize and how first-choice interest is considered.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_B. School_B is my first choice, and I’m applying because I’m highly motivated to join your community and would enroll if admitted. I’m looking for a rigorous environment and would be excited to contribute both academically and through school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, so I should apply immediately rather than risk losing the only seat. Although School_B’s priority list ranks me 3rd (behind Student_D and Student_A), applying now is still optimal because there is no cost to trying first and it preserves the chance that higher-priority students choose other schools. I will signal strong commitment and fit to encourage acceptance if they can.

conversation.message: Dear Student_B, thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_B. After review in this round, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time. We appreciate your enthusiasm for our community and wish you the very best in the rest of the matching process.
conversation.thought: Student_B is 3rd on School_B’s true priority list (behind Student_D and Student_A). In round 1, only Student_B has applied to us, and they rank us #1, so accepting would secure a match immediately. However, Student_D (our top choice) ranks School_B #3 and will likely apply first to School_D (#1) or School_C/School_A depending on outcomes; Student_A ranks School_B #4, so less likely to apply early. Given quota=1 and the goal to match as high as possible on our priority list, it is worth waiting at least a round or two to see if Student_D (or Student_A) becomes available; rejecting now keeps capacity open. Student_B can pursue other schools where they may also do well, and we can reconsider only if still unmatched later (though rules don’t specify re-application limits, rejection is safer than premature acceptance).

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions—I'm Student_A and School_A is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I strongly prefer your academic environment and would commit to enrolling if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A. Although School_A ranks me 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_D), applying immediately is still optimal because if either higher-priority student applies there, I likely lose the seat anyway; delaying doesn’t improve my priority. I’ll make a clear [APPLY] to signal strong commitment and fit.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_A is your first choice. After reviewing applications for this round and considering our selection priorities, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your interest in School_A and wish you the best in the remainder of the process.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_A is 3rd on School_A’s true priority list (behind Student_B and Student_D). Although Student_A ranks School_A first and is applying now, accepting would immediately fill our only seat and foreclose the chance to match with higher-priority Student_B or Student_D, who may apply in later rounds (they each rank School_A 3rd and 2nd respectively). Given we can reject now and still potentially secure a higher-priority match later, the optimal strategy is to reject Student_A at this time.

conversation.message: Hello School_D—I'm Student_C. School_D is my first choice, and I’m applying because I strongly want to join your community. I’m especially interested in the academic environment and would fully commit if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, so I should apply immediately. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd), and early application can secure the only seat before other students (especially Student_D and Student_E, who are ranked above me) commit. I will clearly express strong fit and commitment to increase the chance of acceptance.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for placing School_D as your first choice. We appreciate your strong commitment and interest in our academic environment. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: School_D has quota 1 and ranks Student_C third (behind Student_D and Student_E). Student_C is applying now and lists School_D as first choice, so accepting would lock in a decent-ranked student immediately. However, Student_D (our top choice) ranks School_D last and is unlikely to apply; Student_E ranks School_D fourth and may not apply early. Given the risk of ending unmatched or matched with a lower-priority student later, accepting Student_C now secures a high-enough outcome within our true priority list.

conversation.message: Dear School_A Admissions Committee—I'm Student_B. I’m applying to School_A because I’m seeking a challenging academic environment with a strong community, and I believe I would be a great fit. If admitted, I would be excited to enroll and contribute both in the classroom and through extracurriculars. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: School_B (my top choice) already rejected me, likely holding out for higher-priority applicants. Among remaining unmatched schools, School_A is my 3rd choice but I am School_A’s top priority, so an [APPLY] should secure an acceptance and avoid risking being left with only lower options later. I’ll express strong fit and clear intent to enroll if admitted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for your thoughtful note. After reviewing our priorities for this round, we are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. We believe you would be a strong fit for our community and would be excited to have you join us.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_B is #1 on School_A's true priority list. We have quota 1 and no current matches. Student_B has applied, so accepting now secures our top-choice student and there is no benefit to waiting for a higher-ranked candidate (none exists).

conversation.message:
Dear School_B Admissions,

I’m Student_A and I’m submitting my application to School_B. I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your school community, and if admitted I would be ready to enroll. Thank you for considering my application.

Among remaining options, School_B is higher on my true list than School_E and I have relatively strong priority at School_B (2nd after Student_D). I will apply to School_B now to try to secure a good match before capacity is taken.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for your application and for your enthusiasm for School_B. After reviewing your application this round, we are pleased to offer you admission to School_B. We would be excited to welcome you to our community.

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: School_B quota is 1. True priority ranks: D > A > B > C > E. In this round, applicants are Student_A and Student_E; A is higher priority than E. Student_B already applied earlier and was rejected; D has not applied yet, but waiting risks losing A to another school (A prefers A/C/D over B). Accepting A now secures a high-priority match (2nd choice on our list) and is better than holding out uncertainly for D. Therefore accept Student_A.

conversation.message:
Dear School_B Admissions Team,

I’m Student_E, and I’m writing to formally apply to School_B. School_B is one of my top choices because I’m excited by the academic rigor and the student community, and I’m confident I would contribute through consistent effort, collaboration with classmates, and active involvement in school activities.

If admitted, I would be ready to commit and would be grateful for the opportunity to join School_B.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: School_C (my top choice) is already filled, and among the remaining unmatched schools, School_B is my next highest true preference. Although School_B ranks me last in its priority list, it is still optimal to apply now because seats are scarce and delaying risks losing all acceptable options. I will emphasize strong fit and commitment while keeping the message concise and direct.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_B. At this time, our available seat has already been filled, so we’re not able to offer you admission in this round.

We appreciate the time and care you put into your application, and we wish you the very best with the rest of the matching process.

Sincerely,
School_B Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: Student_E applied, but School_B’s remaining quota is 0 and we are already matched with Student_A (who is higher on our true priority list than Student_E). Per rules, with quota 0 we must reject any new [APPLY].

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Team,

I’m Student_E, and I would like to formally apply to School_E. While I have explored other options earlier in the process, I have strong respect for School_E’s community and academic environment, and I believe I would be a reliable, positive contributor—through consistent effort in coursework, collaboration with peers, and active participation in school life.

If offered admission, I am ready to accept and commit promptly. Thank you for considering my application.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (ranked 5th). Since higher-ranked schools have already filled their seats, applying now maximizes my chance of securing a match rather than ending unmatched. I will signal sincere interest and readiness to commit if accepted, while briefly emphasizing fit and contribution.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your thoughtful application and for your interest in School_E. After reviewing your application in the context of our current admissions process and limited remaining capacity, we are not able to offer you admission at this time.

We sincerely appreciate the time and care you put into your message, and we wish you the very best with your other school options.

Respectfully,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). We have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. Student_E is applying now and offers immediate commitment. However, higher-priority students (A/C/B) may still be available and are unlikely to rank School_E highly (A has E last; C has E last; B has E 4th), meaning they might come later only if rejected elsewhere. With limited rounds remaining but still time (round 3/30), it is strategically better to hold the seat for a chance at A/C/B rather than lock in E now. Therefore, reject Student_E to preserve capacity for higher-priority candidates.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions Team,

I’m Student_E. I previously applied and understand that you could not offer a seat at that time due to limited capacity. Since School_E is currently still available, I’d like to reaffirm my interest and formally apply again.

If admitted, I will accept promptly and commit. I would bring steady effort in academics, reliability in group work, and positive participation in the school community.

Thank you for reconsidering my application.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though lowest). I was previously rejected because their seat was filled; since they are now unmatched, capacity may have reopened. To maximize my chance of matching rather than remaining unmatched, I should re-apply with a concise update and clear commitment.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E and for reapplying. After reviewing your application in the context of our current admissions process and remaining seat availability, we are pleased to offer you admission to School_E.

Please reply with your confirmation of acceptance so we can finalize enrollment steps.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: We have 1 seat and must maximize outcome per our true priority: A > C > B > E > D. Student_E is 4th on our list, acceptable but not ideal. However, no other students are currently applying to us this round, and holding the seat risks ending unmatched if higher-priority students never reach us (they all rank School_E last). Given Student_E is on our acceptable list and is actively applying/committing, accepting now secures a match rather than likely remaining empty.
